int-org-section.p: The European Commission, like the European Parliament (EP) and the Council of the European Union, was established in the 1950s under the EU’s founding treaties. The functions of the Commission are fourfold: to propose legislation to the EP and the Council; to implement EU policies and programmes adopted by the EP and to manage and implement the budget; to enforce European law, in conjunction with the Court of Justice, in all the member states; and to represent the EU in international affairs and to negotiate agreements between the EU and other organizations or countries.

A new Commission is appointed for a five-year term, normally within six months of the elections to the EP. The European Council nominates an individual for the post of Commission President. The nominee must then be elected by the EP by majority vote; if the Parliament fails to elect the nominated candidate, a new candidate must be nominated within a period of one month. The Governments of member states then nominate the other members of the Commission, who must be approved by the EP. In the performance of their duties, the members of the Commission are forbidden to seek or accept instructions from any government or other body, or to engage in any other paid or unpaid professional activity. Once approved, the Commission may nominate a number of its members as Vice-President. Any member of the Commission, if they no longer fulfil the conditions required for the performance of their duties, or commit a serious offence, may be removed from office by the Court of Justice. The Court may, furthermore, on the petition of the Council or of the Commission itself, provisionally suspend any member of the Commission from their duties. The EP has the authority to dismiss the entire Commission by adopting a motion of censure.

The members of the Commission, also known as the College, meet once a week and a collective decision is made on policy following a presentation by the relevant Commissioner. The Commission’s staff is organized into Directorates-General and Services. Each Directorate-General is responsible for a particular policy area and they devise and draft the Commission’s legislative proposals, which become official when adopted by the Commission.

Following allegations of fraud, mismanagement and nepotism within the Commission, in March 1999 two new codes of conduct for Commissioners were announced, and a Committee of Independent Experts published a report that criticized the Commission’s failure to control, inter alia , the administration of the budget. The Commission duly agreed to resign. In November 2005 the Commission launched the Euro­pean Transparency Initiative, with the aim of strengthening ethical rules for EU policymakers, increasing the transparency of lobbying and ensuring the openness of the institutions.

On 1 May 2004 the 20 existing members of the Commission were joined by 10 new members (one from each new member state). For the first six months of their term of office, although considered full members, they worked alongside existing Commissioners and were not allocated their own departments. From November, when a new Commission began its mandate, there were 25 members of the Commission, one from each member state as stipulated by the Treaty of Nice (prior to 1 May, large countries had been permitted two Commissioners, while smaller countries had one). In January 2007, following the accession of Bulgaria and Romania, the number of Commissioners increased to 27, the number increasing to 28 following Croatia’s accession to the EU in July 2013.

A Commission led by Jean-Claude Juncker of Luxembourg took office on 1 November 2014. A new Commission for 2019–24, led by Ursula von der Leyen of Germany, took office on 1 December 2019, comprising 27 Commissioners (anticipating the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, which took place on 31 January 2020).
